snippet.textDisplay: I totally empathize with how you feel! On 3-11 I smashed my thumb and index finger in a form die set up in a hydraulic brake press. Luckily, it's a machine I had been running for 17yrs and was very familiar with and aware of what it could do to one's fingers so I got my foot off the pedal before it got REALLY bad. Long story short, index finger turned out to be just a huge blood blister, but the thumb was ripped open on the side and a tiny piece of bone broken off the knuckle. Wounds are all healed now, except the bone... which will take a few weeks longer. Still kinda achy and unable to bend completely. But yeah, I too feel embarrassed and mad about the whole thing. A few days after the 11th they laid us all off due to the coronavirus, so I was able to heal in the comfort of my home and now I'm itching to get back to work once the "stay at home" order is lifted.

snippet.textDisplay:
Go to a hospital right away with this type of injury. A deep space hand infection spreads easily to the entire palm with devastating consequences. "flexor tenosynovitis is clinically suspected treatment should be commenced immediately to prevent flexor-tendon adhesions or necrosis. Early treatment should include intravenous antibiotics administration, elevation, splinting and close monitoring" https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6540949/

"In these cases, time is important
and swift, accurate identification and management are directly related to clinical outcomes"
https://www.jhandsurg.org/article/S0363-5023(17)31725-2/pdf

snippet.textDisplay: talking about finger injuries makes me feel it in my nuts. as if it happened yesterday.. I was trueing my mountain bikes wheels one day. I had my bicycle upside down and I was moving the back wheel with the pedals. this bike had big disc brakes with rotors that had lots of open spaces in them. I wasn't paying attention as the wheel was moving quite fast and one of my fingers slipped in between the rotor and the bikes frame. it stopped instantly on my finger. it hurt so bad it had my whole body shaking. now when I see bad injuries like that it makes me cringe so bad.

snippet.textDisplay:
15 years in the machine shop has shown me the most dangerous people are the newbies who don't know that something is dangerous and the highly experienced machinists who "have done it that way a thousand times." In my career I saw one guy rip his finger off using sandpaper to deburr a ½-13 internal thread (because he didn't want to change the settings to reverse the spindle direction...which would have meant that when the piece of sandpaper caught a burr, it would have ejected the sandpaper rather than suck it in...along with his finger), another get his finger ripped off by the adjustment opening in a shaper head on a turret lathe (he was setting up a new cutting tool and didn't think it was necessary to repeatedly open and close the window on a rotating piece of equipment), and a third destroy his hand because he bypassed a safety mechanism on a boring mill (in order to use the rapid traverse on this particular machine, you have to put the crank handle into an interlock hole so that you won't have a 24" inch long handle in the spinning dial for moving the table...he tried to speed up his job by taking the handle from another boring mill of the same model...he got smacked by a 24" x 1" steel handle rotating at about 600 RPM and shattered every bone in his hand).


Thanks for sharing this, Adam, because holy shit machine shops are dangerous places to be, but when you go so long without anything bad happening, you can get complacent for juuuuust long enough for something really bad to happen.

snippet.textDisplay:
You lost me at "I took this rag....".
I know what happened. You tried to clean the lead screws with a rag while the machine was running.
It's ok. It happens. We love our machines. We start to feel like they are a part of us. We get COMFORTABLE with them.
We most often get bitten while "petting" them.
Usually right after a major repair.
I'm not going to watch the rest of this unless someone tells me I got it wrong and there's something to learn from this I might have missed...
I caught my finger in my table router once. Didn't even want to look at it after was sure it was mangled like a flower.
Wasn't too bad. A little super glue after putting all the pieces back together and it was ok.
Get back on that horse. You don't want to be afraid of a machine that serves so many purposes. A lathe is a terrible thing to waste.

snippet.textDisplay:
So TECHNICALLY, the rag gave your finger an indian burn so fast, powerful and insane.... that it split your skin like a hot dog over a fire :0
OR, it managed to wrap your finger between the rope and wheel....lengthwise...along your finger and you managed to pull away as it clamped your finger tight lengthwise, hence pulling your finger apart.


OR...When a wound up cloth textile is quickly pulled tight - especially if there is an object within the coil/wound up cloth similar to a finger in a chinese handcuffs toy - then it will hold that object .. in the case of a very very fast lathe, it would have been milliseconds that saved his finger and allowed for it to essentially foldout and away like a bread loaf rising in oven splitting apart, or a hot dog in a fire.....the physics of the action with pressure within it being exerted on the outer 'shell' (like your finger in a wound up rag, quickly pulled away)... the action of you pulling away with all your body weight probably gave it just the right amount of exertion from within and outward to give it that bread roll/hot dog slit effect... but at the same time having had gripped your skin and replicated this gesture.....literally pulling your skin apart, but so fast... soo fast..



in either case it definitely pulled your skin apart, not your typical standard clean slice
shivers



As a little girl on a military base I saw a guy with leather gloves punch a man in the face who started a fight with him, and it gripped his cheek and pulled it away leaving a gaping hole/flap.
What you got is more like that, but turned into an Indian Burn and on your finger, so more like a roasted weener. I can't imagine my finger looking like a roasted weener, i hope it heels!!!!

snippet.textDisplay: I used to work in a internal upholstery fabric warehouse and processing center and I was a machine operator. On one occasion I was working with a cutting machine and it had these massive spinning cylinders to pull the fabric along and behind growing roll of fabric was a mechanical yard counter as this was a very old machine. Well the fabric got so high I couldn't read it so I stood up and leaned over the fabric roll to see how many yards had gone through and right then the my hoodie string got sucked into the machine. I reached for my belt knife but my buddy was quicker and hit the e-stop and cut the hoody string with his scissors in one quick smooth motion. I hate to think what might have happened to me if he wasn't there.

Be extra safe while a pandemic or similar is happening. Being over confident or distracted in these times is just asking for trouble. Injuries cant always be prevented but now is the time to minimize the risk as much as possible.

snippet.textDisplay:
It's not just a thing for helicopters, its true generally in all aviation particularly military. You'll typically always have one junior and one senior person fly together. Two senior people are too comfortable/cavalier/complacent to be safe and two junior people are too inexperienced. One of each is perfect because the senior won't want to teach the junior one poorly, and the junior one will be fresh from training and careful in the fundamentals.

Don't get complacent or comfortable when using high power equipment!!

snippet.textDisplay:
We've all done stuff like that. The good thing is that you did not de-glove yourself. Most people will end up doing just that by pulling there fingers, or hand, anything cought out of the pinch point. It is just a simple reaction that you do without thinking. I've done it while out plowing, gashed my thumb about an inch in two spots, luckily I did not de-glove myself in the process, that would have been a fun call to the boss.

You should always practice good safety procedures when working with a lathe, just like you said, you get to comfortable with your tools and end up paying a price.
I'm not familiar with that lathe, but most have a lever to disengage the transmission, and make it so that you can turn the acne screw by hand when the machine is off, it will take longer, but compared to this, it is worth it.

snippet.textDisplay: I feel your pain and shame completely.  I got my hand pulled through a dough sheeter by my own stupid fault as well.  It was a machine I had used for years and trained people on the safe use of it.  I had the exact same moment you spoke of where I was concerned I was going to lose my hand to a crush injury and the fear of looking at my hand to see what had happened.  Two of my fingers split open down to the bone and I heard a series of pops and my hand went numb.  Thankfully I only suffered two fractures, got 20 some odd stitches, and some third degree burns from the friction.  I had flashbacks for days as well but they passed and after 4 months of healing and physical therapy I have 100% functionality.  I still use the same machine and remind anyone who uses it to respect its power and hold up my scarred hand to drive the point home.

snippet.textDisplay: Man, I almost lost my left thumb due to a freak accident while working with plate glass. Background: lifetime professional drummer, I own a home improvement company, and I’m a licensed home inspector. My hands are my life. Anyway, I was working a job removing 3’ x 4’ pieces of plate glass. One shattered and cut my thumb and hand. I cut my thumb so bad I had to have 12 stitches in the tip of my thumb. That being said, 2 weeks later I was installing a glass shower door and even though I knew the shower glass door was tempered and would break into tiny cubes and not glass shards, I had a small panic attack and was sweating and shaking. So weird how a severe injury can mentally impact you. Get well and take care of your finger! I’m glad you are ok. I have been watching you for years and love your show!

snippet.textDisplay:
Adam, I'm sorry for saying this, but you have violated one of the basic safety rules of working with machines. No long shirts, no rings, no rags, no gloves, and always protect your eyes.

But it's actually really important in my opinion to have "controlled" accidents. An accident where the instructor let's you "almost" get hurt, but not. That shaking feeling is an important lesson. People who don't ever get told, shown or otherwise experience a minor accident, I think they don't really understand how safe or unsafe they are.

Because there's no way to be in a controlled accident that doesn't leave a scar, it is important to have safety training and to have it in a continuous monthly basis.

At work, they give us computer based training complete with mini tests on various topics. At home I review my machines to see if they are still safe to operate (old stuff) every time I use it.

Anyway, I'm a critic, but I definitely don't do enough in my opinion, so thanks for sharing, and hey maybe start your own safety program. "Safety third" is funny but it hurts.

People who don't ever get told, shown or otherwise experience a minor accident, I think they don't really understand how safe or unsafe they are.

Because there's no way to be in a controlled accident that doesn't leave a scar, it is important to have safety training and to have it in a continuous monthly basis.

snippet.textDisplay: I've met quite a few woodworkers over the years with a missing digit or two and 90%+ were seasoned pros who got bit because of complacency. One guy wasn't a pro and he was just being stupid. Anyway, this is an important thing and Adam deserves all the credit for sharing his experience. I always tell people to hang on to a little bit of a healthy fear when working with machines. Complacency is what will get you every time. FYI, I'm not immune to these mistakes and I've just been lucky that no emergency room visits were required.

snippet.textDisplay:
Adam - thank you for posting this. I'm just some Joe Random who's loved your work for YEARS, but it's a great reminder for all of us amateurs to remember that shop machines are dangerous at all times. Just because we become accustomed to the danger, doesn't mean that the danger is gone. Never let your guard down. Always respect the machine.

I know what you mean about shame and self-anger. The finger might have gotten mangled, but forgive yourself for your error. Everyone (you) is OK. We forgot to respect a machine and its dangers for one minute a couple years ago, and proceeded to roll a tractor. I'm still aware of the shame of that accident every time I start it up. In my case, someone died. It wasn't the machine's fault, though.

Stay safe, and keep doing what you love.

snippet.textDisplay:
I had a similar thing happen about ten years ago with a drill press of all things. It really is always the tools your not scared of that get you! I was honing out some holes in some metal strap. I was trying to rig my drill press into an automated bore honing machine. These strap segments were kinda sharp so I thought I'd wear gloves... The 13/32 drill bit (yes, I even know which one it was) grabbed the part, the part grabbed the glove and pulled me in. The glove wrapped my arm up in the drill press. The drill cut into my forearm and I now have a 2.5" scar to remember this all by. Thankfully, twas but a flesh wound! I did need stitches, but didn't nick anything important or break my arm as I had initially feared. Really it didn't even bleed. I was insanely lucky. Power tools, even the ones that seem safe, are no joke!


Also, smart move bringing your mom out to stay with you!

The drill cut into my forearm and I now have a 2.5" scar to remember this all by.  Thankfully, twas but a flesh wound!  I did need stitches, but didn't nick anything important or break my arm as I had initially feared.  Really it didn't even bleed.  I was insanely lucky. Also, smart move bringing your mom out to stay with you!

snippet.textDisplay: When I was 14 I caught my finger in a 30k rpm metal bench grinder while in welding class. Somebody had set the tool rest back about an inch from the wheel, and they didn't replace it. My piece of metal got sucked down into it, and my finger touched the wheel for about half a second. It took a fat chunk out of my index finger, and I had to get a skin graft. Scary scary shit. I've never been complacent with machinery since.

Like you said - being a maker means you get hurt sometimes. And that's OK... as long as those hurts are minor, and as long as you learn from them. snippet.textDisplay:
we've got pollen happening here in WV, Every time I sneeze or cough, i have to ask "is that Covid, or my allergies????!?!?!"

My grandfather had a sign on the wall of his shop Not sure where he got it (I suspect from an old high school wood shop) that had the ABCs of Safety...
top of the list:
Always pay ATTENTION to what you're doing
Think BEFORE you cut
CONSIDER how you will do the whole cut

it was extensive....and the few times an injury happened in the shop (thankfully, all were minor...) as we were bandaiding, or usually just looking to see how bad it was, he'd ask "which one did you forget?" and he'd nod at the sign....

we've got pollen happening here in WV,  Every time I sneeze or cough, i have to ask "is that Covid, or my allergies????!?!?!"   

My grandfather had a sign on the wall of his shop   Not sure where he got it (I suspect from an old high school wood shop) that had the ABCs of Safety... 
top of the list:
  Always pay ATTENTION to what you're doing
 Think BEFORE you cut
 CONSIDER how you will do the whole cut

it was extensive....and the few times an injury happened in the shop (thankfully, all were minor...)  as we were bandaiding, or usually just looking to see how bad it was, he'd ask "which one did you forget?" and he'd nod at the sign....

snippet.textDisplay: I feel for you, Adam.  A few weeks ago, I was replacing a wheel hub bearing and couldn't remove it.  Started using an angle grinder on it without the safety.  I use my angle grinder all the time, and I have sort of developed this false sense of security.  Had a grinder wheel break and strike me in the ear, cutting a quarter inch slice in it.  I immediately thought I'd lost my ear.  Brought me back to reality with the respect I need to give my tools at all times.
